717802f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Dyckman Street
717802f-b.text:
Broadway, at Dyckman Street. Visw 1 shows the G. F. Gantz
house at the northwest corner of the intersection. View 2
shows an old house at Bennett avenue.
E. P. Chrystie  June 1e, 1923
CDDI LINE IMUPERATIVE  Views 1,2

719390f-a.title: Manhattan: Dyckman Street - Riverside Drive
719390f-a.text:
Gravevard of Mt. Vashington Presbyterian Church, near the
intersection of Dyckman Street and Riverside Drive.
1904.
Brovn Prothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
719390f-a.folder: Dyckman Street & Riverside Drive, Manhattan, NY

722863f-a.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Dyckman Street
722863f-a.text:
Riverside Drive, at Dyckman Street, showing the new link conneoting
same with the Henry Hudson Parkway via a bridge over Dyckan Street
and from which the photographer is viewing southward in No. 1.
Formerly the Drive followed the contour of the stone wall and turned
eastward to Broadway, skirting Fort Tryon Park in which the Cloisters,
a branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art is under construction.
Southwest of game is the new George Washington Bridge across the North
(Hudson) River at 181st Street. View No. 2 is northward from a point
below the new Museum and across the Dyckman Street gap to Inwood Hill
Park.
June 22, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
An earlier view of the same area. Note the original condition
of Riverside Drive (cars thereon). The photographer states his
vantage point to be near Dyckman Street and the Railroad.
722863f-a.folder: Riverside Drive & Dyckman Street, Manhattan, NY

717800f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Dyckman Street
717800f-b.text:
Broadway and environs at Dvckmar Street, as viewed north-
vard from Fort George, Broadvay is the thoroughfare iust this
side of Inwood Hill (hnoll in the left cer ter) and runs across
the view from right to left: Dvckn an Street beino at the foot
of same passinc thru the gap formed, bevord which apnear the
Palisades of Ne v Uersey as mounds in the far distance. To the
rioht is the Metropolitan Railroad Co. power plant on the Harlem
River at the foot of W. 216th Street, silhouetted agaiust the
Marble Hill otline of the Bronx Shore. This set consists of a
photostatic positivw aud negative. For additional views at this
date see Inwood Hill Park.
1904.
Brownn Bros.
NO RPRODUCTIONS.

717803f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Dyckman Street
717803f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, at Dyckman Street, as viewed northeastward on
Riverside Drive at Seaman Ave. Note the one story structures at both
the S.E. and N.E. corners. The 6-story apartment house shown is No. 209
Dyckman Street, north side, east of Broadway.
September 14, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.

717805f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Riverside Drive
717805f-a.text:
At the intersection of Broadway and Riverside Drive, at Dyckman
Street.
Ootober 26, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

719389f-a.title: Manhattan: Dyckman Street - Broadway
719389f-a.text:
Dyckman Street, south side, from but not including Broadway, to
but not including Pavson Ave.
October 26, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

1509033-a.title: Broadway #225 - Dyckman Street, looking southeast
1509033-a.folder: Broadway #225 - Dyckman Street, looking southeast, Manhattan, NY

717806f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Dyckman Street
717806f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Dyckman to Cummings Streets, showing
construction work on the Dyckman Street station of the Eighth Avenue
subway.
October 26, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

717801f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Dyckman Street
717801f-a.text:
Broadway and environs at Dyckman Street, as viewed northward
from Fort Georce. Broadway is the thoroughfare iust this side of
Inwood Hill (Enoll in the left center) and runs across the view from
rimht to left; Dyckman Street being at the foot of same passing thru
the gap formed, beyond which appear the Palisades of New Jersey as
mounds in the far distance. To the right is the Metropolitan Railroad
Commpany power plant on the Harlem River at the foot of W. 216th Street,
silhouetted against the Marble Hill outline of the Bronx Shore. For
additional views at this date see Inwood Hill Park.
1904
Brown Brothers
NO REPRODUCTIONS

722862f-c.title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Dyckman Street
722862f-c.text:
(1)
The intersection of Riverside Drive, (Boulevard Lafayette) and
Dyckman (Inwood) Street, at Broadway, (  ). The view
shows the Mount Washington Presbyterian Church (a frame structure),
with the Parish House, adjoining. The Church was built in 1844-46, at
''Tubby Hook'', on the site of the old Black Horse Tavern of 1812.
October 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
.-
(2)
The same, a more includive view, showing the new Dyck Arms Apts.,
adjoining on the drive side.
October 26, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
The same as No. 2, after the dhurch and Parish House have been
demolished.
June 3, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
722862f-c.folder: Riverside Drive & Dyckman Street, Manhattan, NY
